body_text.text: On 11 February 2020 the World Health Organisation declared the COVID-19 outbreak a 14 pandemic and since then there has been a race against the clock to readjust healthcare systems, to 15 limit the spread, to find a treatment or to develop a vaccine. Our department reduced the medical staff to the minimum necessary to perform emergency interventions and all other procedures were cancelled after careful revision. 1 Here, we present our point of view regarding the preparation needed of a vascular unit for the 2 end of COVID-19 crisis. The extrapolation can help other units to find the best way to organise 3 and to foresee upcoming events.

Aorta. For EVAR and TEVAR preparation is needed re-evaluate the cases that are fit for 5 outpatient procedures 5 and re-evaluate the priority according to the risk of rupture and the need 6 of post-procedural intensive care. For FEVAR procedures and other custom-made prostheses that 7 are already manufactured, attention must be paid to ensure that CT scans are not older than 6 8 months. 9 Carotid. An ultrasound exam must be provided followed by a medical visit after the lockdown is 10 lifted, in order to confirm permeability, mostly for tight lesions, to ensure usual follow-up and to 11 prepare the further interventions if necessary 6 .

Iliac arteries and peripheral artery disease. Most of these patients can be treated as outpatient 13 procedures, but care must be taken to identify the patient at risk of complications. In order to 14 plan interventions for PAD patients, pre-operatory exams must be scheduled: US exams to 15 evaluate the permeability, venous cartography for bypasses and angiography for BTK General consideration. The use of operating theatres must be prepared in conjunction with other 23 surgical units. For inpatient capacity, a network of rehabilitation centres, home-care nurses and 1 telemedicine 8 must be organized to ensure an optimal in-flow and out-flow of patients. Vascular 2 patients must not become collateral damage of COVID-19, continuity of follow-up is key. The 3 current crysis is unexpected and unique and we need to find solutions, be innovative and to hope 4 for the best and prepare for the worst.
